ratings.comment: The professor wants her students to succeed and is very supportive in terms of providing feedback or assistance when a paper is due. The class is reading heavy and also features a lot of slides during lecture. The grading was very reasonable and fair.

A semester with Professor Chan was absolutely amazing! This class is a MUST TAKE for anyone who is interested in learning about China and the country's history. The papers that I had to write were challenging but very rewarding. Overall, I would recommend this class to all my friends.
Professor Chan lectures at you most of the time, but the reading load is manageable and there are only five papers for the whole semester. If you try on these, the class should be easy enough.

Her lectures are fairly interesting and in general she does a good job of covering the course material. She does assign a lot of reading, sometimes as much as 150-200 pages per class, which can be difficult to get through, but much of the material is covered in lecture. Don't skip assignments though since there are only a few, and two are midterms.

Professor Chan has high expectations for writing ability, especially given that the majority of the class is freshmen and sophomores. Could be more specific with what she expects. Tests are based almost completely on lectures and often require special attention.

I enjoy the lectures a lot. She covers things clearly and she is always willing to answer questions. The exam isn't hard because everything comes from the study guide, and cheat sheet is allowed. The paper isn't long. 1 page, double-spaced for the first two assignments (4 total). Extra credits are given, which is a plus.

"Chinese Migrations" was mostly interesting and appropriately difficult.  The grading was fair and sometimes generous. I really liked Chan. She's no nonsense, has a variety of interests, and seemed genuine.

She is awful and over demanded.she may require you to write as a PH.D students. I think that is her goal. She is totally confusing and bad at teaching. Never feel like to attend to the lecture. The only reason drives to there is attendance. And I'm sure even you go to every lecture, you won't get full credits for paticipation.

Shelly Chan is overall confusing.  She has expectations that are completely unrealistic and out of line for such a low level course.  She will make recommendations on what you should do in you papers and even if you follow them exactly she will tell you they are wrong.  If you put effort in she almost acts annoyed that you are making an attempt.

Lots of writings and not easy to get AB or A. Writing assignments are sometimes confusing. Topics are interesting, hope she can talk more about Chinese history. 85% of time we are just writing or researching.
too harsh in grading. Classes are not bad. nearly impossible to get A in papers, even AB is not usual. only two power lectures a week, no discussion. Not so recommended if you want a A.
Kinda harsh in grading. Not very encouraging. I spent lots of time on my papers and still only got Bs or BCs. The movie class is kinda interesting tho.

Absolutely ridiculous in grading. Never gives As and rarely ABs. I have no idea about the grading standards of those papers. Some papers got As and they were just average and some got Bs or BCs for some minor mistakes. Your B or BC paper might have a greater chance to get AB or A in other 201 classes. Avoid this class if you can.
Prof. Chan is really clear in explaining the changes of Chinese society before/after 1949. Know a lot about her materials. A bit of a harsh grader but very fair. Recommended.
